en: So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
vi: Alice đang cân nhắc xem nếu cô kết một vòng hoa cúc thì có thú vị hơn không, có đáng để cô phải đứng dậy và đi hái hoa không (Cái nóng oi ả của ngày hè khiến Alice buồn ngủ và đầu óc trở nên mụ mị). Đúng lúc đó, đột nhiên, một chú Thỏ Trắng có đôi mắt màu hồng chạy ngang qua ngay sát chỗ cô ngồi.
vi_results: "title": "Alice ở Xứ Sở Thần Tiên","author": "Lewis Carroll"
tr: Bunun üzerine düşünmeye başladı (pek de düşünemiyordu ya, hava çok sıcaktı, onun da uykusu gelmiş, serseme dönmüştü), acaba papatyalardan bir çelenk örmek, papatya toplamak yorulduğuna değer mi diye aklından geçiriyordu. Tam o sırada birden pembe gözlü bir Beyaz Tavşan koşarak yanından geçti.
es: Así pues, estaba pensando (y pensar le costaba cierto esfuerzo, porque el calor del día la había dejado soñolienta y atontada) si el placer de tejer una guirnalda de margaritas la compensaría del trabajo de levantarse y coger las margaritas, cuando de pronto saltó cerca de ella un Conejo Blanco de ojos rosados.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Alice was considering whether it would be more interesting if she made a daisy chain, and whether it was worth getting up and picking flowers (The sultry summer heat made Alice sleepy and her mind become dull). Just then, suddenly, a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran past right near where she was sitting.
tr_translation: He began to think about it (though he couldn't really think, the weather was very hot, and he was sleepy and dazed), wondering if making a wreath from daisies or picking daisies was worth the effort. Just then, a White Rabbit with pink eyes suddenly ran past him.
es_translation: Thus, she was thinking (and thinking required some effort from her, because the heat of the day had left her drowsy and dazed) whether the pleasure of weaving a daisy garland would be worth the effort of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes jumped near her.
st: Kahoo o ne a nahana ka kelello ea hae (hape le eena a ka khona, hobane letsatsi le chesang le ile la etsa hore a ikutloe a robetse haholo le leoatla), hore na thabo ea ho etsa daisy-ketane e ne e tla ba ea bohlokoa ho tsoha le ho nka li-daisies, ha ka tšohanyetso Mmutla o Mosoeu o nang le mahlo a pinki a ile a matha haufi le eena.
yo: Nítorí náà ó ń ronú nínú ọkàn ara rẹ̀ (gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ti lè ṣe é, fún ọjọ́ gbígbóná jẹ́ kí ó ní ìmọ̀lára oorun àti òmùgọ̀), bóyá ìdùnnú láti ṣe daisy-chain yóò tó ìṣòro láti dìde kí ó sì mú àwọn daisies, nígbà tí White Rabbit lójijì pẹ̀lú ojú aláwọ̀ píkì súnmọ́ ọn.
tn: Ka jalo o ne a akanya ka mogopolo wa gagwe (le fa a ne a kgona, ka gonne letsatsi le le mogote le ne la dira gore a ikutlwe a robetse thata e bile a le bosilo) a itumelela go dira gore go nne le bothata jwa go tsoga le go tsaya di-daisies, fa ka ponyo ya leitlho le lesweu le le pinki le ne la tabogela kwa go ene.
ty: No reira, ua feruri oia i roto i to'na iho feruriraa (mai ta'na e nehenehe, no te mea i te mahana ve'ave'a, ua vai noa te hinaaro i roto ia'na ia taoto e ia maamaa), mai te mea e, e mea maitai a'e ia ti'a i ni'a e ia ohi i te mau daisies, i te taime a horo mai ai te hoê rapiti uouo e te mata tarona i piha'i iho ia'na.
mai: तेँ ओ अपन मनमे विचार कऽ रहल छलीह (जतेक भऽ सकैत छलीह, किएक तँ गर्मीक दिन हुनका बहुत नीन आ बेवकूफ अनुभव करबैत छल), कि डेजी-चेन बनयबाक सुख उठबाक आ डेज़ी चुनबाक कष्टक लायक होयत, जखन अचानक गुलाबी आँखिवला एकटा उज्जर खरगोश हुनका लग दौड़ि गेल।

en: Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs. She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled “ORANGE MARMALADE”, but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.
vi: Không hiểu do cái giếng quá sâu hay do cô rơi xuống chậm mà trong lúc rơi xuống, cô vẫn có khá nhiều thời gian để quan sát xung quanh và tự hỏi điều gì sẽ xảy ra kế tiếp. Thoạt đầu cô cố gắng nhìn xuống dưới để nhận biết phía trước là cái gì. Nhưng trong giếng tối quá nên cô chẳng nhìn thấy gì. Rồi cô nhìn xung quanh và nhận ra những chiếc kệ đựng cốc chén và giá sách được gắn đầy thành giếng. Đây đó còn có những tấm bản đồ và những bức tranh treo trên móc. Alice cầm lấy một cái bình trên kệ khi cô rơi ngang qua. Chiếc bình có dán mảnh giấy đề “Mứt cam” nhưng bên trong chẳng còn tí mứt nào. Thất vọng quá nhưng Alice không muốn ném cái bình xuống giếng vì sợ nhỡ đâu nó sẽ làm chết ai đó. Thế là cô phải cố đặt chiếc bình lên một cái giá khác khi cô rơi ngang qua.
vi_results: "title": "Alice ở xứ sở thần tiên","author": "Lewis Carroll"
tr: Ya kuyu çok derindi, yahut Alice çok yavaş yuvarlanıyordu: Çünkü düşerken çevresine bakınacak, arkasından neler gelecek bakalım, diye düşünecek vakit buldu. Alice önce nereye gittiğini görmek için aşağı bakmaya çalıştı ama çevre o kadar karanlıktı ki hiçbir şey seçemedi: Sonra kuyunun yanlarına bakmaya başladı, duvarların kitap rafları ve dolaplarla kaplanmış olduğunu gördü. Şurada burada da tahta çivilere asılmış haritalar, resimler vardı. Raflardan birinin önünden geçerken bir kavanoz aldı: Kavanozun üstüne ''Portakal Reçeli'' yazılı bir etiket yapıştırılmıştı, ama kavanozun içi boş çıkınca Alice'in çok canı sıkıldı. Kavanozu aşağı atacaktı, sonra birinin kafasına gelip öldürüverir diye korktu, ne yapıp yapıp düşerken önünden geçtiği raflardan birine koyuverdi.
es: O el pozo era en verdad profundo, o ella caía muy despacio, porque Alicia, mientras descendía, tuvo tiempo sobrado para mirar a su alrededor y para preguntarse qué iba a suceder después. Primero, intentó mirar hacia abajo y ver a dónde iría a parar, pero estaba todo demasiado oscuro para distinguir nada. Después miró hacia las paredes del pozo y observó que estaban cubiertas de armarios y estantes para libros: aquí y allá vio mapas y cuadros, colgados de clavos. Cogió, a su paso, un jarro de los estantes. Llevaba una etiqueta que decía: MERMELADA DE NARANJA, pero vio, con desencanto, que estaba vacío. No le pareció bien tirarlo al fondo, por miedo a matar a alguien que anduviera por abajo, y se las arregló para dejarlo en otro de los estantes mientras seguía descendiendo.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Not sure if it was because the well was too deep or because she was falling slowly, but while falling, she still had quite a bit of time to observe her surroundings and wonder what would happen next. At first, she tried to look down to see what was ahead. But the well was too dark, so she couldn't see anything. Then she looked around and noticed shelves filled with cups and bookshelves attached to the well's walls. Here and there, there were also maps and pictures hanging on hooks. Alice grabbed a jar from a shelf as she fell past. The jar had a label that read "Orange Marmalade" but there wasn't any marmalade left inside. Disappointed, Alice didn't want to throw the jar down the well for fear that it might kill someone. So she tried to place the jar on another shelf as she fell past.
tr_translation: Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and bookshelves. Here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs. She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labeled "ORANGE MARMALADE," but to her great disappointment it was empty. She did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.
es_translation: Either the well was truly deep, or she was falling very slowly, because Alice, while descending, had plenty of time to look around and wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and see where she would end up, but it was too dark to make out anything. Then she looked at the walls of the well and observed that they were covered with cupboards and bookshelves: here and there she saw maps and pictures, hanging from nails. She took a jar from one of the shelves as she passed. It had a label that said: ORANGE MARMALADE, but she saw, with disappointment, that it was empty. She didn't think it would be right to throw it to the bottom, for fear of killing someone who might be down there, and managed to place it on another shelf as she continued descending.
st: Mohlomong se ne se le botebo haholo, kapa o ile a oela butle haholo, kaha o ne a e-na le nako e ngata ha a ntse a theoha ho ea sheba ka eena le ho ipotsa hore na ho tla etsahalang kamora moo. Pele, o ile a leka ho sheba fatše le ho etsa seo a neng a tla ho sona, empa ho ne ho le lefifi haholo ho bona letho; 'Me o ile a sheba ka mahlakoreng a seliba, 'me o ile a hlokomela hore ba ne ba tletse lik'haboteng le lishelefo buka. Ha a le moo, o ile a bona 'mapa le litšoantšo tse neng li le holim'a lipitsa. 'Me o ile a nka nkho ho tloha e' ngoe ea lishelefong ha a ntse a feta. E ne e bitsoa "ORANGE MARMALADE", empa ho soetseha ha hae ho hoholo ho ne ho se na letho: o ne a sa rate ho lahla nkho ka lebaka la ho tšaba ho bolaea motho e mong ka tlase, kahoo a khona ho e kenya ho e 'ngoe ea lik'hilojule ha a oela.
yo: Bóyá kànga náà jinlẹ̀ gan-an, tàbí ó ṣubú díẹ̀díẹ̀, nítorí ó ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àkókò bí ó ṣe ń sọ̀kalẹ̀ láti wò ó àti láti ṣe ìyàlẹ́nu ohun tí yóò ṣẹlẹ̀ lẹ́yìn náà. Lákọ̀ọ́kọ́, ó gbìyànjú láti wo ìsàlẹ̀ kí ó sì ṣe ohun tí ó ń bọ̀ sí, ṣùgbọ́n ó ti dúdú jù láti rí ohunkóhun; Lẹ́yìn náà ó wo ẹ̀gbẹ́ kànga náà, ó sì ṣàkíyèsí pé wọ́n kún fún àwọn kọ́bọ́ọ̀dù àti àwọn pẹpẹ ìwé; Níbí àti níbẹ̀ yẹn ó rí àwọn máàpù àti àwọn àwòrán tí wọ́n gbé kọ́ sórí ẹsẹ̀. Ó gbé ìgò kan sọ̀kalẹ̀ láti inú ọ̀kan nínú àwọn pẹpẹ bí ó ṣe ń kọjá; Wọ́n pè é ní "ORANGE MARMALADE", ṣùgbọ́n sí ìjákulẹ̀ ńlá rẹ̀ ó ṣófo: kò fẹ́ràn láti ju ìkòkò náà sílẹ̀ nítorí ìbẹ̀rù láti pa ẹnìkan ní abẹ́ rẹ̀, nítorí náà ó gbìyànjú láti fi sínú ọ̀kan nínú àwọn kọ́bọ́ọ̀dù bí ó ṣe ṣubú kọjá rẹ̀.
tn: Gongwe o ne a le moleele thata, kana o ne a wela ka bonya thata, ka a ne a na le lobaka lo lo lekaneng fa a ntse a ya go mo leba a bo a ipotsa gore go tla diragala eng morago ga foo. Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a leka go dira se a neng a se dira, mme go ne go le thata go bona sengwe le sengwe. Yaba o sheba difahleho, mme a bona hore di tletse difahleho le difoto tsa dibuka. Fa a le koo, o ne a bona dimmapa le ditshwantsho tse di neng di le mo godimo ga dimmapa. 'O ne a tlhôla nnyana mo lesetaneng' - She took a jar from one of the shelves as she passed 'O ne a tlhômamisa' - The orange marmalade, mme go ne go se na sepe se a neng a se na sepe: O ne a sa rate go bolaya motho yo o neng a tshaba go bolaya mongwe ka fa tlase ga gagwe, ka jalo o ne a kgona go e tsenya mo go nngwe ya di-cupboards fa a sena go e feta.
ty: E mea hohonu roa te apoo pape, e aore râ, ua topa mărû noa oia, no te mea, e taime rahi to'na a pou ai oia i raro no te hi'o ia'na e no te uiui e, eaha te ohipa e tupu i muri iho. A tahi, ua tamata oia i te hi'o i raro e i te imi i te mea ta'na e haere mai, e mea poiri roa râ ia hi'o i te hoê mea ; i muri iho ua hi'o atu oia i te hiti o te apoo pape, e ua ite atu e ua î te reira i te mau vairaa buka e te mau vairaa buka; i ǒ nei e i reira, ua ite oia i te mau hoho'a fenua e te mau hoho'a i faatautauhia i nia i te mau pepe. Ua rave mai oia i te hoê mohina i roto i te hoê o te mau paepae a haere atu ai oia; ua parauhia te reira e " ORANGE MARMALADE ", tera râ, no to'na inoino rahi, aita e taata i roto : aita oia i au ia faaru'e i te mohina no to'na ri'ari'a i te taparahi pohe i te hoê taata i raro a'e i te reira, e no reira, ua manuïa oia i te tuuraa i te reira i roto i te hoê o te mau afata a topa ai oia na piha'i iho ia'na.
mai: या तँ इनार बहुत गहींर छल, या ओ बहुत धीरे-धीरे खसि पड़लीह, किएक तँ हुनका लग बहुत समय छल जखन ओ अपन विषयमे देखबाक लेल नीचाँ जाइत छलीह आ आश्चर्य करैत छलीह जे आगाँ की होबय जा रहल अछि। पहिने ओ नीचा देखबाक प्रयास कयलनि आ पता करबाक प्रयास कयलनि जे ओ की लग आबि रहल छथि, मुदा किछु देखबा लेल बहुत अन्हार छल; तखन ओ इनारक कातमे देखलीह, आ देखलनि जे ओ अलमारी आ किताबक अलमारीसँ भरल छल; अईठाम आ ओतए ओ खूँटा पर लटकल नक्शा आ चित्र देखलीह। गुजरैत काल ओ एकटा अलमारीक एकटा जार उतारि लेलक। एकरा "ऑरेंज मार्मेलेड" लेबल देल गेल छल, मुदा हुनका बहुत निराशा भेल जे ई खाली छल: ओ ककरो नीचा मारबाक डरसँ जार छोड़ब पसन्द नहि करैत छलीह, तेँ एकरा एकटा अलमारीमे रखबामे सफल रहलीह जहिना ओ ओहिसँ खसि पड़लीह।
mg: Na tena lalina ilay lavadrano, na nianjera moramora izy, satria nanam-potoana betsaka izy rehefa nidina nijery azy sy nanontany tena hoe inona no hitranga manaraka. vi_translation: Everyone managed to get ashore, but they were all in a miserable state. The birds dragged their wet, bedraggled feathers along the ground, while the animals had their fur and whiskers matted against their bodies. Everyone was soaked and felt uncomfortable and irritated.
tr_translation: This group gathered on the shore looked really strange: the birds' feathers were ruffled, the other animals' fur was stuck to their bodies, and they were all soaking wet; they had frowns on their faces and stood uncomfortably.
es_translation: The group that gathered on the shore had a really strange appearance: the birds with dirty feathers, the other animals with their fur stuck to their bodies, and all of them soaked to the bone, grumpy and uncomfortable.

en: “I know what ‘it’ means well enough, when I find a thing,” said the Duck: “it’s generally a frog or a worm. The question is, what did the archbishop find?”

es: —¡Claro que sé lo que quiere decir! —refunfuñó el Pato—. Cuando yo encuentro algo es casi siempre una rana o un gusano. Lo que quiero saber es qué fue lo que encontró el arzobispo.
es_results: "El Pato" is a character from the book "El Pato Donald" but also appears in "Winnie the Pooh" by A.A. Milne
vi_translation: "I understand very well what 'that' means when I see something," said the Duck, "usually it's a frog, sometimes it's a worm." "But I want to ask what the archbishop saw?"
tr_translation: The duck said, "When I find it myself, I know what it is." "What I find is either a worm or a frog. But I want to know what the archbishop found."''
es_translation: —grumbled the Duck—. When I find something, it's almost always a frog or a worm. What I want to know is what the archbishop found.

en: By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time with the words “DRINK ME,” but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips. “I know something interesting is sure to happen,” she said to herself, “whenever I eat or drink anything; so I’ll just see what this bottle does. I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”
vi: Đúng lúc đó, Alice nhận ra mình đang đi vào một căn phòng nhỏ nhưng ngăn nắp. Trong phòng kê một chiếc bàn cạnh cửa sổ và trên bàn (đúng như Alice hy vọng) có một chiếc quạt và hai, ba đôi găng tay; vừa định bước ra khỏi phòng thì chợt nhìn thấy một cái chai nhỏ để gần tấm gương soi. Cái chai này không có nhãn đề chữ “HÃY UỐNG TÔI”, nhưng Alice vẫn mở nút chai và ghé môi uống thử. Cô nghĩ: “Mình biết chắc bất cứ lúc nào mình ăn hay uống cái gì đó, thể nào cũng có chuyện thú vị xảy ra. Vậy thì mình chỉ việc chờ đợi xem cái chai này sẽ có tác dụng gì. Hy vọng nó sẽ làm mình to ra như trước đây bởi thật ra mình đã quá mệt mỏi vì phải làm một người bé tí như thế này!”

tr: Bu arada derli toplu küçük bir odaya gelmişti: Bu odanın penceresinin içinde bir masa, masanın üstünde de (Alice'in umduğu gibi) iki üç çift eldivenle bir yelpaze duruyordu. Bir çift eldivenle yelpazeyi aldı, tam odadan çıkıyordu ki gözüne aynanın yanında duran küçücük bir şişe ilişti. Bu şişenin üstünde ''Beni iç'' yazılı bir yafta yoktu, ama Alice tıpasını açarak şişeyi ağzına dayadı. Kendi kendine, ''Ne zaman bir şey içsem yahut yesem kesinlikle acayip bir şeyler oluyor'' dedi. ''Bakalım bu şişenin marifeti ne. Beni yine büyütür umarım. Çünkü bu kadar küçük kalmaktan bıktım artık.
es: A todo esto, había conseguido llegar hasta un pequeño dormitorio, muy ordenado, con una mesa junto a la ventana, y sobre la mesa (como esperaba) un abanico y dos o tres pares de diminutos guantes blancos de cabritilla. Cogió el abanico y un par de guantes, y, estaba a punto de salir de la habitación, cuando su mirada cayó en una botellita que estaba al lado del espejo del tocador. Esta vez no había letrerito con la palabra «BEBEME», pero de todos modos Alicia lo destapó y se lo llevó a los labios. —Estoy segura de que, si como o bebo algo, ocurrirá algo interesante —se dijo—. Y voy a ver qué pasa con esta botella. Espero que vuelva a hacerme crecer, porque en realidad, estoy bastante harta de ser una cosilla tan pequeñaja. ¡Y vaya si la hizo crecer!
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Just at that moment, Alice realized she was entering a small but tidy room. In the room, there was a table by the window, and on the table (just as Alice had hoped) there was a fan and two or three pairs of gloves; just as she was about to leave the room, she suddenly noticed a small bottle near the mirror. This bottle did not have a label saying "DRINK ME," but Alice still opened the cap and took a sip. She thought, "I know for sure that whenever I eat or drink something, something interesting is bound to happen. So I just have to wait and see what effect this bottle will have. I hope it will make me grow big again because I'm really tired of being such a tiny person like this!"
tr_translation: In the meantime, she had come to a neat little room: Inside the window of this room was a table, and on the table (as Alice had hoped) there were two or three pairs of gloves and a fan. She took a pair of gloves and the fan, and was just about to leave the room when she noticed a tiny bottle standing next to the mirror. There was no label on this bottle that said "Drink Me," but Alice uncorked it and put it to her lips. She said to herself, "Whenever I drink or eat something, something strange always happens." "Let's see what this bottle can do." I hope it makes me grow again. Because I'm tired of staying this small.''
es_translation: In all this, she had managed to reach a small, very tidy bedroom, with a table by the window, and on the table (as she expected) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves. She picked up the fan and a pair of gloves, and was about to leave the room when her gaze fell on a small bottle that was next to the mirror on the dresser. This time there was no label with the word "DRINK ME," but nevertheless Alice uncorked it and brought it to her lips. —I am sure that if I eat or drink something, something interesting will happen —she said to herself—. And I am going to see what happens with this bottle. I hope it makes me grow again, because, in reality, I am quite tired of being such a tiny little thing. And boy, did it make her grow!

mai: एहि समय धरि ओ खिड़कीमे एकटा टेबुलक संग एकटा साफ-सुथरा छोट कोठरीमे प्रवेश कऽ चुकल छलीह, आ ओहि पर (जेना ओ आशा कयने छलीह) एकटा पंखा आ दू-तीन जोड़ी छोट-छोट उज्जर बच्चाक दस्ताना: ओ पंखा आ दस्तानाक एकटा जोड़ी उठौलनि, आ बस कोठरीसँ बाहर निकलय जा रहल छलीह।  जखन ओकर आंखि एकटा छोट बोतल पर पड़ल जे देखय बला ग्लास के लग मे ठाढ़ छल। एहि बेर "ड्रिंक मी" शब्दक संग कोनो लेबल नहि छल, मुदा तइयो ओ एकरा खोलि अपन ओठ पर राखि देलनि। "हम जनैत छी जे किछु रोचक होयब निश्चित अछि," ओ अपनासँ कहलनि, "जखन हम किछु खाइत छी या पीबैत छी; त हम बस देखब जे ई बोतल की करैत अछि। हम आशा करैत छी जे ई हमरा फेरसँ पैघ कऽ देत, किएक तँ वास्तवमे हम एतेक छोट चीज होयबाक कारणे बहुत थाकि गेल छी!"

en: And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.

es_translation: And so she continued discoursing for a good while, sometimes in one direction and other times contradicting herself, ultimately maintaining a very serious conversation, as if it were between two people. es: Se puso de puntillas, y miró por encima del borde de la seta, y sus ojos se encontraron de inmediato con los ojos de una gran oruga azul, que estaba sentada encima de la seta con los brazos cruzados, fumando tranquilamente una larga pipa y sin prestar la menor atención a Alicia ni a ninguna otra cosa.

vi_translation: She stood on tiptoe and had just seen the top of the mushroom when her eyes also caught sight of a large dark green caterpillar sitting on it. tr_translation: She stood on tiptoe and took a peek over the edge of the mushroom. And what did she see but a huge blue Caterpillar sitting with its arms crossed, smoking a long-necked hookah, paying no attention to Alice or anything else.
es_translation: She stood on tiptoe and looked over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met the eyes of a large blue caterpillar, which was sitting on top of the mushroom with its arms crossed, calmly smoking a long pipe and paying no attention whatsoever to Alice or anything else.

en: She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit. Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.
vi: Cô hốt hoảng bởi sự thay đổi quá nhanh nhưng đồng thời cũng thấy không được lãng phí thời gian bởi vì cô đang co lại rất nhanh và thế là cô lập tức tìm cách ăn một ít nấm còn lại ở tay bên kia. Lúc đó, cằm cô đã ép sát vào chân đến nỗi phải chật vật lắm mới há được miệng đủ rộng để cắn một miếng nấm. Cuối cùng cô cũng nuốt được một miếng nấm nhỏ ở tay bên trái.

es: Se asustó mucho con este cambio tan repentino, pero comprendió que estaba disminuyendo rápidamente de tamaño, que no había por tanto tiempo que perder y que debía apresurarse a morder el otro pedazo. Tenía la mandíbula tan apretada contra los pies que resultaba difícil abrir la boca, pero lo consiguió al fin, y pudo tragar un trocito del pedazo de seta que tenía en la mano izquierda.

vi_translation: She was alarmed by the rapid change but at the same time felt she shouldn't waste any time because she was shrinking very quickly, so she immediately tried to eat some of the remaining mushroom in her other hand. By then, her chin was pressed so close to her foot that she had to struggle to open her mouth wide enough to take a bite of the mushroom. Finally, she managed to swallow a small piece of the mushroom in her left hand.
tr_translation: Changing so quickly had frightened him a lot; he thought he had no time to lose while shrinking so fast, and he tried to chew the other piece. But since his feet were pressed against his chin, there was no room to open his mouth; finally, he managed to take a bite from the piece in his left hand with difficulty.
es_translation: She was very frightened by this sudden change, but she understood that she was rapidly decreasing in size, that there was no time to lose, and that she had to hurry to bite the other piece. Her jaw was so tightly pressed against her feet that it was difficult to open her mouth, but she finally managed it, and was able to swallow a small piece of the mushroom she held in her left hand.

en: As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent. She had just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made her draw back in a hurry: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and was beating her violently with its wings.
vi: Bởi vì hình như chẳng có cách gì đưa tay lên đầu, Alice đành phải cúi đầu xuống và cô vui mừng thấy cái cổ cũng có thể cúi xuống một cách dễ dàng và quay đi quay lại mọi phía giống như một con rắn. Cô cũng có thể uốn cong cái cổ theo hình zíc zắc và chuẩn bị sục sạo trong đám lá để tìm đôi tay (đám lá này chính là tán cao nhất trên ngọn cây mà lúc trước cô đi ở dưới). Đúng lúc đó, một tiếng kêu lảnh lót khiến cô vội lùi lại: một con bồ câu lớn lao vào mặt cô và đang dùng đôi cánh của nó đánh cô tới tấp.
vi_results: "title": "Alice ở xứ sở thần tiên","author": "Lewis Carroll"
tr: Artık ellerini başına götüremeyeceğini anlayınca başını ellerine götürmeyi denedi, bir de baktı ki boynunu yılan gibi istediği yana kolayca çevirebiliyor. Boynuyla hoş bir zikzak çizerek, yaprakların arasına dalmak üzereyken onların demin aralarında dolaştığı ağaçların tepelerinden başka bir şey olmadığını gördü, tam o sırada keskin bir ıslık işitti, hemen kafasını kaldırdı. Koca bir güvercin üstüne doğru gelmiş kanatlarıyla pat pat yüzüne vuruyordu.
es: Como no había modo de que sus manos subieran hasta su cabeza, decidió bajar la cabeza hasta las manos, y descubrió con entusiasmo que su cuello se doblaba con mucha facilidad en cualquier dirección, como una serpiente. Acababa de lograr que su cabeza descendiera por el aire en un gracioso zigzag y se disponía a introducirla entre las hojas, que descubrió no eran más que las copas de los árboles bajo los que antes había estado paseando, cuando un agudo silbido la hizo retroceder a toda prisa. Una gran paloma se precipitaba contra su cabeza y la golpeaba violentamente con las alas.
es_results: "title": "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland", "author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Because it seemed there was no way to raise her hand to her head, Alice had to bend her head down and she was delighted to see that her neck could also bend down easily and turn around in all directions like a snake. She could also bend her neck in a zigzag shape and prepare to rummage through the leaves to find her hands (these leaves were the highest branches of the tree she had been walking under earlier). At that moment, a shrill cry made her quickly retreat: a large pigeon flew into her face and was beating her incessantly with its wings.
tr_translation: When she realized that she could no longer bring her hands to her head, she tried to bring her head to her hands, and she saw that she could easily turn her neck in any direction like a snake. He saw that there was nothing but the tops of the trees they had just been wandering among, as he was about to dive among the leaves, drawing a pleasant zigzag with his neck, and at that moment he heard a sharp whistle and immediately lifted his head. A huge pigeon was coming towards him, flapping its wings and hitting his face.
es_translation: Since there was no way for her hands to reach her head, she decided to lower her head to her hands, and discovered with enthusiasm that her neck bent very easily in any direction, like a snake. She had just managed to lower her head through the air in a graceful zigzag and was about to insert it among the leaves, which she discovered were nothing more than the tops of the trees under which she had previously been walking, when a sharp whistle made her retreat in a hurry. A large pigeon was rushing at her head and hitting it violently with its wings.
st: Joalokaha ho ne ho bonahala eka ha ho na monyetla oa ho phahamisetsa matsoho a hae hloohong, o ile a leka ho mo isa hlooho ho bona, 'me a thaba ho fumana hore molala oa hae o tla khumama habonolo tseleng efe kapa efe, joalo ka noha. O ne a sa tsoa atleha ho e curving ka zigzag e nang le mohau, 'me o ne a tla qoela har'a makhasi, eo a ileng a fumana ho se letho haese litlhōrō tsa lifate tseo a neng a ntse a lelera ka tlas'a tsona, ha mohlape o bohale o ile a etsa hore a hule ka potlako: le pigeon e khōlō e ne e fofetsoe sefahlehong sa hae,  'Me o ne a otla ka mabifi ka mapheo a eona.
yo: Bí ó ṣe jọ pé kò sí àfààní láti gbé ọwọ́ rẹ̀ sókè sí orí rẹ̀, ó gbìyànjú láti gbé orí rẹ̀ sọ̀kalẹ̀ fún wọn, inú rẹ̀ sì dùn láti rí i pé ọrùn rẹ̀ yóò tẹ̀ nírọ̀rùn ní ọ̀nà èyíkéyìí, bíi ejò. Ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ṣe àṣeyọrí nínú gbígbé e sọ̀kalẹ̀ sínú zigzag oore-ọ̀fẹ́, ó sì máa wọlé láàrin àwọn ewé, èyí tí ó rí pé kò jẹ́ nkankan bí kò ṣe òkè àwọn igi lábẹ́ èyí tí ó ti ń rìn kiri, nígbà tí tirẹ̀ tó mú jẹ́ kí ó fa padà ní kíákíá: ẹyẹlé ńlá kan ti fò sí ojú rẹ̀,  Ó sì ń fi ìyẹ́ rẹ̀ lù ú pẹ̀lú ìyẹ́ rẹ̀.
tn: Fa a ne a lebega a se na tshono ya go tsholetsa diatla tsa gagwe, a leka go mo tshikinya tlhogo, mme a itumelela go bona gore molala wa gagwe o tla khubama mo tseleng nngwe le nngwe fela jaaka noga. en: At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came skimming out, straight at the Footman’s head: it just grazed his nose, and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.

es: En este momento la puerta de la casa se abrió, y un gran plato salió zumbando por los aires, en dirección a la cabeza del lacayo: le rozó la nariz y fue a estrellarse contra uno de los árboles que había detrás.

vi_translation: At that moment, the door burst open and a large plate was thrown out by someone, heading straight for the frog-faced servant's head. Luckily, it only grazed his nose and hit a tree behind him, shattering into pieces.
tr_translation: At that moment, the door of the house opened and a large plate was hurled like an arrow towards the Butler's head. It passed just by the tip of his nose and hit a nearby tree, shattering into pieces.
es_translation: At that moment, the door of the house opened, and a large plate came whizzing through the air, heading straight for the footman's head: it grazed his nose and crashed into one of the trees behind him.
st: Ka motsotso ona monyako oa ntlo oa buloa, 'me poleiti e kholo ea tsoa, e otlolohile hloohong ea Footman: e sa tsoa fula nko ea hae, ea roba likotoana khahlanong le e 'ngoe ea lifate tse ka morao ho eena.
yo: Ní àkókò yìí ilẹ̀kùn ilé náà ṣí sílẹ̀, àwo ńlá kan sì jáde, tààrà sí orí Footman: ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ jẹ imú rẹ̀, ó sì fọ́ sí àwọn ege sí ọ̀kan nínú àwọn igi tó wà lẹ́yìn rẹ̀.
tn: Ka yona nako eo kgoro ya ntlo e ne ya bulwa, mme letlapa le legolo la tswa le tsubile mo tlhogong ya Footman: le ne le sa tswa go fula nko ya gagwe, la robaganya le lengwe la ditlhare tse di fa morago ga gagwe.

en: The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark, “It was the best butter, you know.”
vi: Thỏ rừng cũng lại rút một chiếc đồng hồ quả quýt ra và rầu rĩ nhìn nó. Đột nhiên nó nhúng cả chiếc đồng hồ vào tách nước trà rồi lại nhìn, nhưng nó chẳng nghĩ được điều gì hay hơn là câu nói ban đầu: - Đó là loại bơ tốt nhất đấy, anh biết thế mà.

tr: Mart Tavşanı saati alarak üzgün üzgün baktı, sonra cup diye çay fincanına daldırıp çıkardı, yine baktı, ama gene ilk dediğinden daha iyi bir söz bulamadı. ''İnan olsun, en iyi tereyağıydı.
es: La Liebre de Marzo cogió el reloj y lo miró con aire melancólico: después lo sumergió en su taza de té, y lo miró de nuevo. Pero no se le ocurrió nada mejor que decir y repitió su primera observación: —Era mantequilla de la mejor, sabes.
es_results: "Las Aventuras de Alicia en el País de las Maravillas", "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: The hare also took out a pocket watch and looked at it sorrowfully. Suddenly, it dipped the watch into a cup of tea and looked at it again, but couldn't think of anything better to say than its initial remark: - That's the best butter, you know that.
tr_translation: The March Hare took the watch and looked at it sadly, then dipped it into the tea cup with a plop, took it out, looked at it again, but still couldn't find a better word than what he had said first. "I assure you, it was the best butter."''
es_translation: The March Hare took the watch and looked at it with a melancholic air: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again. But nothing better occurred to him to say, so he repeated his first observation: —It was the best butter, you know.
st: The Hlakubele Hare o ile a nka oache mme a e sheba ka mokhoa o letšo-letšo: joale a e kenya ka senoelong sa hae sa tee, 'me a e sheba hape: empa o ne a sa nahane ka letho le molemo ho feta polelo ea hae ea pele, "E ne e le botoro e ntle ka ho fetisisa, ua tseba."
yo: March Hare mú aago náà ó sì wò ó pẹ̀lú ìbànújẹ́: lẹ́yìn náà ó fi sínú ife tíì rẹ̀, ó sì tún wò ó: ṣùgbọ́n kò lè ronú nípa ohunkóhun tí ó dára jù láti sọ ju ọ̀rọ̀ àkọ́kọ́ rẹ̀ lọ, "Bọ́tà tí ó dára jùlọ ni, o mọ̀."

tr_translation: At this part of the song, the Field Mouse gave a little shake and started muttering in his sleep. ''Shiny, shiny, shiny, shiny.'' He dragged it out so much that they pinched him to make him stop.
es_translation: Upon reaching this point, the Dormouse shivered and began to hum in his sleep: "twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle...", and he went on like that for so long that they had to give him a good pinch to make him stop.

en: The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on: “—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are “much of a muchness”—did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?”
vi: Lúc này, Chuột sóc đã nhắm tịt hai mắt lại và bắt đầu ngủ, nhưng bị Người làm mũ véo một cái, nó choàng dậy, hét một tiếng nhỏ rồi lại tiếp tục kể. - Bắt đầu bằng chữ M, thí dụ như cái bẫy chuột, mặt trăng, ký ức[15] và nhiều thứ giống như thế.

F ile başlayan şeyler söz gelimi, fare kapanı, fırça fazlalık filan hani konuşurken de fazla fazlalık denir ya. Siz hiç kuyudan 'fazlalık' çekilmesi diye bir şey gördünüz mü?
es: Para entonces, el Lirón había cerrado los ojos y empezaba a cabecear. Pero, con los pellizcos del Sombrerero, se despertó de nuevo, soltó un gritito y siguió la narración: —... lo que empieza con la letra M, como matarratas, mundo, memoria y mucho... muy, en fin todas esas cosas. Mucho, digo, porque ya sabes, como cuando se dice "un mucho más que un menos". ¿Habéis visto alguna vez el dibujo de un «mucho»?
es_results: "Las Aventuras de Alicia en el País de las Maravillas" by Lewis Carroll
vi_translation: At this moment, the Dormouse had tightly closed its eyes and started to sleep, but the Hatter pinched it, causing it to wake up with a small scream and then continue its story. - Starting with the letter M, for example, a mouse trap, the moon, memories[15], and many things like that. You know, you always say these things are "exactly the same," but have you ever seen something exactly like the thing you pulled?
tr_translation: Meanwhile, the Mouse, having closed its eyes, was falling asleep. But when the Hatter pinched it, it woke up with a scream and started telling its story: ''... Things that start with F, for example, mouse trap, brush, surplus, you know, when talking, you also say excessive surplus. Have you ever seen anything like 'excess' being drawn from a well?
es_translation: By then, the Dormouse had closed its eyes and was starting to nod off. But, with the Hatter's pinches, it woke up again, let out a little squeak, and continued the narration: —... what starts with the letter M, like mouse-trap, world, memory, and much... very, well all those things. Much, I say, because you know, like when one says "a much more than a less". Have you ever seen a drawing of a "much"?

en: Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. “That’s very curious!” she thought. “But everything’s curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.” And in she went.
vi: Nói đến đây, Alice bỗng phát hiện ra một cái cây có cửa dẫn vào trong thân. “Kỳ lạ chưa! Nhưng ngày hôm nay cái gì mà chẳng kỳ lạ. Có lẽ mình nên vào trong đó xem sao.” Nghĩ vậy Alice bước qua cửa và tiến vào trong thân cây.

es: Mientras decía estas palabras, descubrió que uno de los árboles tenía una puerta en el tronco. —¡Qué extraño! —pensó—. Pero todo es extraño hoy. Creo que lo mejor será que entre en seguida. Y entró en el árbol.

vi_translation: As she said this, Alice suddenly discovered a tree with a door leading inside its trunk. “How strange! But then again, everything today has been strange. Maybe I should go inside and see.” Thinking this, Alice stepped through the door and entered the tree trunk.
tr_translation: Just as she was saying this, she noticed a door in one of the trees: "What a strange thing!" she thought. Then, "Well, everything is strange today anyway! Let me go through this door and see," she said and entered through the door.
es_translation: While saying these words, he discovered that one of the trees had a door in its trunk. —How strange! —he thought—. But everything is strange today. I think the best thing will be to go in right away. And he entered the tree.

en: Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table. “Now, I’ll manage better this time,” she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and then—she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.
vi: Một lần nữa, Alice lại thấy mình đang đứng giữa gian sảnh dài ngay cạnh cái bàn thủy tinh nhỏ. “Lần này mình sẽ làm mọi việc tốt hơn.” Cô tự nhủ và bắt đầu bằng việc cầm lấy chiếc chìa khóa nhỏ bằng vàng và mở cánh cửa dẫn vào khu vườn. Thế rồi, cô lại cắn một miếng nấm (cô vẫn giữ miếng nấm trong túi) và nhấm nháp cho tới khi cô cao khoảng 1 foot. Sau đó, cô men theo lối đi nhỏ và cuối cùng cô đã đứng giữa khu vườn tuyệt đẹp, xung quanh là những bông hoa rực rỡ và đây đó là những đài phun nước mát lạnh.

tr: Bir de baktı ki yine o uzun salonda, cam masanın yanı başında duruyor. ''Eh, artık bu kez ne yapacağımı daha iyi biliyorum'' diye kendi kendine söylendi ve önce küçük altın anahtarı almakla işe başladı. Sonra o güzel bahçeye giden kapıyı açtı; sonra oturdu, bir ayak boyu oluncaya kadar mantarı kemirdi (bir parçasını cebinde saklamıştı): sonra o küçük koridordan yürüdü ve sonunda serin çeşmeler akan, güzel renkli çiçekler dolu bahçeye erişti.
es: Una vez más se encontró en el gran vestíbulo, muy cerca de la mesita de cristal. «Esta vez haré las cosas mucho mejor», se dijo a sí misma. Y empezó por coger la llavecita de oro y abrir la puerta que daba al jardín. Entonces se puso a mordisquear cuidadosamente la seta (se había guardado un pedazo en el bolsillo), hasta que midió poco más de un palmo. Entonces se adentró por el estrecho pasadizo. Y entonces... entonces estuvo por fin en el maravilloso jardín, entre las flores multicolores y las frescas fuentes.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Once again, Alice found herself standing in the long hall right next to the small glass table. “This time I will do everything better.” She told herself and began by taking the small golden key and opening the door leading to the garden. Then, she took a bite of the mushroom (she still kept the piece of mushroom in her pocket) and nibbled until she was about 1 foot tall. After that, she followed the small path and finally stood in the beautiful garden, surrounded by vibrant flowers and here and there were cool fountains.
tr_translation: Then she found herself once again in that long hall, standing right next to the glass table. "Well, this time I know better what to do," she said to herself and started by taking the small golden key. Then she opened the door leading to that beautiful garden; then she sat down and nibbled the mushroom until she was about a foot tall (she had kept a piece in her pocket): then she walked through that small corridor and finally reached the garden filled with beautiful colored flowers and cool fountains.
es_translation: Once again she found herself in the great hall, very close to the little glass table. “This time I’ll do things much better,” she said to herself. And she started by taking the little golden key and opening the door that led to the garden. Then she began to nibble carefully on the mushroom (she had kept a piece in her pocket), until she measured just over a handspan. Then she went through the narrow passage. And then... then she was finally in the wonderful garden, among the multicolored flowers and the fresh fountains.
st: Ka nako e 'ngoe o ile a iphumana a le ka kamoreng e telele, 'me haufi le tafole e nyane ea khalase. "Jwale, ke tla laola nako ena," a rialo a le mong, mme a qala ka ho nka senotlolo sa kgauta se senyenyane, le ho bula monyako o ileng wa kena serapeng. 'Me o il'o robala ka har'a bona, 'me o il'o robala ka har'a bara ba hae, 'me o il'o robala ka har'a bona.
yo: Lẹ́ẹ̀kan síi ó rí ara rẹ̀ nínú gbọ̀ngàn gígùn, ó sì súnmọ́ tábìlì gíláàsì kékeré náà. "Ní báyìí, mà á ṣàkóso dáadáa ní àsìkò yìí," ó sọ fún ara rẹ̀, ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ nípa gbígba kọ́kọ́rọ́ wúrà kékeré, àti ṣíṣí ilẹ̀kùn tí ó yọrí sí ọgbà. Lẹ́yìn náà ó lọ síbi iṣẹ́ tí ó ń jẹ olú náà (ó ti tọ́jú nkan kan nínú rẹ̀ sínú àpò rẹ̀) títí tí ó fi ga ní bíi ẹsẹ̀ kan: lẹ́yìn náà ó rìn sọ̀kalẹ̀ ní ọ̀nà kékeré: lẹ́yìn náà - ó rí ara rẹ̀ nígbẹ̀yìn nínú ọgbà tó rẹwà, láàrin àwọn ibùsùn òdòdó tí ó mọ́lẹ̀ àti àwọn orísun omi tó tutù.
tn: O ne a tlhola a iphitlhela a le mo phaposing e telele, a bo a le gaufi le tafole e nnye ya galase. "Jwale, ke tla laola nako ena," a rialo ka boena, mme a qala ka ho nka senotlolo se senyane sa kgauta, le ho bula monyako o neng o eteletse pele serapeng. 10Yaba o ya le tshimong ya hae, mme a tsamaya ka maoto a hae, mme a tsamaya ka hara serapana sa hae, mme a ema hara tshimo ya hae, a e kgumamela, mme a e ja.
ty: Ua parahi faahou oia i roto i te piha roa, e ua tapiri atu i te iri amuraa maa na'ina'i. " I teie nei, e manuïa vau i teie taime ", ta'na ïa parau ia'na iho, e ua haamata na roto i te raveraa i te taviri auro na'ina'i, e te iritiraa i te opani e arata'i atu i roto i te aua. I muri iho ua haere atu oia e rave i te ohipa i ni'a i te tari'a (ua tape'a oia i te hoê tuhaa i roto i to'na pute) e tae noa'tu i te hoê metera i te teitei : i muri iho ua haere atu oia na ni'a i te e'a na'ina'i : e i muri iho—ua ite oia ia'na iho i roto i te aua nehenehe, i rotopu i te mau tiare anaana e te mau faataheraa pape to'eto'e.
mai: एक बेर फेर ओ अपना के लम्बा हॉल मे पाबि गेलीह, आ छोट कांच के टेबुल के लग। "आब, हम एहि बेर बढ़िया प्रबंधन करब," ओ अपनासँ कहलनि, आ छोट सुनहरा चाबी लऽ कऽ आ बगीचा दिस जायवला दरवाजाकेँ ताला खोलि कऽ शुरू कयलनि। तखन ओ मशरूममे निबटैत काज पर चलि गेलीह (ओ एकर एकटा टुकड़ा अपन जेबमे राखि लेने छलीह) जा धरि ओ लगभग एक फीट ऊँच नहि छलीह: तखन ओ छोट पैसेजसँ नीचाँ चलि गेलीह: आ तखन—ओ अंततः सुन्दर बगीचामे, उज्ज्वल फूल-बिछौना आ शीतल फव्वाराक बीच भेटलीह।
mg: Indray mandeha indray izy dia nahita ny tenany tao amin'ny efitrano lava sy teo akaikin'ny latabatra fitaratra kely. en: “And who are these?” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
vi: - Thế còn những người này là ai? - Hậu Cơ hỏi Alice, tay chỉ vào những người làm vườn lúc đó đang nằm úp mặt xuống đất quanh cây hoa hồng. Vì họ đều nằm úp mặt xuống đất và những hình vẽ trên lưng họ cũng giống hình vẽ trên tất cả những quân bài khác nên Hoàng hậu không thể biết họ là những người làm vườn, quân lính, hay ba đứa con của bà.

tr: Kraliçe, gül ağacının dibinde yatan üç bahçıvanı göstererek, ''Ya bunlar kim?'' diye sordu. Yüzüstü yatıyorlardı, sırtları da tıpkı öteki iskambil kâğıtlarına benziyordu, onun için Kraliçe bunların bahçıvan mı, yoksa saray ileri geleni mi, yoksa kendi çocuklarından üçü mü olduğunu anlayamamıştı.
es: —¿Y quiénes son éstos? —siguió preguntando la Reina, mientras señalaba a los tres jardineros que yacían en torno al rosal. Porque, claro, al estar de bruces sólo se les veía la parte de atrás, que era igual en todas las cartas de la baraja, y la Reina no podía saber si eran jardineros, o soldados, o cortesanos, o tres de sus propios hijos.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: - Hậu Cơ asked Alice, pointing to the gardeners who were lying face down on the ground around the rose tree. Because they were all lying face down on the ground and the designs on their backs were the same as the designs on all the other cards, the Queen couldn't tell if they were gardeners, soldiers, or her three children.
tr_translation: The Queen, pointing at the three gardeners lying at the base of the rose tree, asked, "Who are these?" They were lying face down, and their backs looked just like the other playing cards, so The Queen could not understand whether they were the gardener, a high-ranking palace official, or three of her own children.
es_translation: —And who are these? —continued the Queen, while pointing to the three gardeners who were lying around the rosebush. Because, of course, being face down you could only see the back, which was the same on all the cards in the deck, and the Queen couldn't tell if they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.

es: —¡Arriba! —gritó la Reina, en voz fuerte y detonante. Y los tres jardineros se pusieron en pie de un salto, y empezaron a hacer profundas reverencias al Rey, a la Reina, a los infantes reales, al Valet y a todo el mundo.
es_results: "Las Aventuras de Alicia en el País de las Maravillas" is the book name and "Lewis Carroll" is the author name.
vi_translation: "Stand up!" - The Queen hissed, her voice shrill and piercing. The three gardeners immediately stood up and bowed to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everyone in the entourage.
tr_translation: The Queen shouted in a ringing voice, "Stand up!"; the three gardeners immediately jumped up and began to salute the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everyone else who was present.
es_translation: "Up!" shouted the Queen, in a loud and explosive voice. And the three gardeners jumped to their feet and began to make deep bows to the King, the Queen, the royal children, the Valet, and everyone.

en: She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”
vi: Cô nhìn quanh để tìm cách thoát khỏi đây và băn khoăn không biết có bị ai nhìn thấy khi chạy trốn không thì đúng lúc đó cô nhận ra một hình bóng kì lạ xuất hiện trong không trung. Thoạt đầu cô hết sức ngạc nhiên nhưng sau vài phút nhìn kỹ, cô nhận ra đó là một nụ cười.

tr: Artık kaçmak için çevrede bir yol arıyor. ''Acaba kimseye görünmeden sıvışabilir miyim?'' diye düşünüyordu; bir de baktı, havada acayip bir şey belirmiş. Önce epeyce şaştı ama bir iki dakika sonra bunun bir gülümseme olduğunu anladı, kendi kendine ''Cheshire Kedisidir'' diye söylendi.
es: Estaba buscando pues alguna forma de escapar, Y preguntándose si podría irse de allí sin que la vieran, cuando advirtió una extraña aparición en el aire. Al principio quedó muy desconcertada, pero, después de observarla unos minutos, descubrió que se trataba de una sonrisa, y se dijo:
es_results: "La sonrisa de la Gioconda" no es el libro, pero la sonrisa es un elemento clave en la historia. Después de analizar el texto, mi suposición es que el libro es "Alicia en el país de las maravillas" de Lewis Carroll.

en: When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
vi: Khi cô quay lại với mèo Cheshire, cô ngạc nhiên thấy một đám đông đang tụ tập ở đó. Một cuộc cãi cọ đang diễn ra giữa đao phủ, Vua và Hoàng hậu. Cả ba cùng nói một lúc trong khi đám đông lặng im và có vẻ rất căng thẳng.
vi_results: "title": "Alice ở xứ sở thần tiên","author": "Lewis Carroll"
tr: Kedi'nin yanına geldiği zaman çevresinde epeyce bir kalabalık biriktiğini görerek şaşaladı. Kral, Kraliçe ve Cellat arasında bir tartışma oluyordu; üçü bir ağızdan konuşuyor, öbürleri de ne yapacaklarını şaşırmış, rahatsız rahatsız duruyorlardı.
es: Cuando volvió junto al Gato de Cheshire, quedó sorprendida al ver que un gran grupo de gente se había congregado a su alrededor. El verdugo, el Rey y la Reina discutían acaloradamente, hablando los tres a la vez, mientras los demás guardaban silencio y parecían sentirse muy incómodos.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: When she turned back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to see a crowd gathering there. An argument was taking place between the executioner, the King, and the Queen. All three were speaking at once while the crowd remained silent and seemed very tense.
tr_translation: When she came near the Cat, she was surprised to see quite a crowd had gathered around. The King, the Queen, and the Executioner were having an argument; the three of them were talking at once, while the others stood around, bewildered and uncomfortable.
es_translation: When she returned to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to see that a large group of people had gathered around it. The executioner, the King, and the Queen were arguing heatedly, all three speaking at once, while the others remained silent and seemed very uncomfortable.
st: Ha a khutlela Cheshire Cat, o ile a makatsoa ke ho fumana bongata bo bongata bo bokelloang ho e potoloha: ho bile le ngangisano e tsamaeang lipakeng tsa mophethi, Morena le Mofumahali, bao kaofela ba neng ba bua ka nako e le ngoe, ha ba bang kaofela ba khutsitse haholo, 'me ba shebahala ba sa phutholoha haholo.
yo: Nígbà tí ó padà sí Cheshire Cat, ó yà á lẹ́nu láti rí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí wọ́n kó jọ yí i ká: àríyànjiyàn kan ń lọ lọ́wọ́ láàárín ẹni tí ó pa á, Ọba, àti Ayaba, tí gbogbo wọn ń sọ̀rọ̀ lẹ́ẹ̀kan náà, nígbà tí gbogbo àwọn yòókù dákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, tí kò sì rọrùn rárá.

en: “When I’m a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen at all. Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—”
vi: Nữ công tước nói tiếp: - Khi ta trở về địa vị Nữ công tước, trong bếp của ta sẽ không còn chút hạt tiêu nào nữa. không có hạt tiêu thì xúp vẫn ngon. Có thể chính hạt tiêu đã làm cho con người ta trở nên nóng tính - Nữ công tước có vẻ rất hài lòng vì đã phát hiện ra một quy luật mới - và giấm khiến người ta trở nên chua ngoa, cúc La mã biến họ thành những kẻ nghiệt ngã và đường làm từ lúa mạch và các thứ tương tự khiến bọn trẻ con trở nên dễ thương. Ta mong sao mọi người đều hiểu điều đó để rồi người ta sẽ không phải miễn cưỡng về điều này, cô hiểu chứ?

'' Kendi kendine yeni kurallar bulduğu için pek hoşnut, düşünmeyi sürdürdü ''Suratsız eden sirke, huysuz eden de arpa şekeriyle buna benzer tatlılardır. es: «Cuando yo sea Duquesa», se dijo (aunque no con demasiadas esperanzas de llegar a serlo), «no tendré ni una pizca de pimienta en mi cocina. La sopa está muy bien sin pimienta... A lo mejor es la pimienta lo que pone a la gente de mal humor», siguió pensando, muy contenta de haber hecho un nuevo descubrimiento, «y el vinagre lo que hace a las personas agrias.,. y la manzanilla lo que las hace amargas... y... el regaliz y las golosinas lo que hace que los niños sean dulces. ¡Ojalá la gente lo supiera! Entonces no serían tan tacaños con los dulces...»
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el País de las Maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: The Duchess continued: - When I return to my position as Duchess, there will be no more pepper in my kitchen. Soup is still delicious without pepper. Perhaps it is the pepper that makes people hot-tempered - The Duchess seemed very pleased to have discovered a new rule - and vinegar makes people sharp-tongued, chamomile turns them into bitter individuals, and barley sugar and similar things make children sweet. I hope everyone understands this so that no one will be reluctant about it, do you understand?
tr_translation: She said to herself, "If I were the Duchess" (though she didn't really expect to be) "I wouldn't keep any pepper in my kitchen. Soup turns out perfectly fine without it. Maybe it's the pepper that makes people quarrelsome." Pleased with herself for coming up with new rules, she continued thinking, "Vinegar makes people sour, and barley sugar and similar sweets make them bad-tempered. Oh, if people knew this, they wouldn't be so stingy."
es_translation: "When I am a Duchess," she said to herself (though not with much hope of ever becoming one), "I won't have a speck of pepper in my kitchen. Soup is just fine without pepper...Maybe it's the pepper that makes people bad-tempered," she continued thinking, very pleased to have made a new discovery, "and vinegar that makes people sour...and chamomile that makes them bitter... and... licorice and sweets that make children sweet. I wish people knew that! Then they wouldn't be so stingy with sweets..."
st: "Ha ke le duchess," a bua ka boeena, (eseng ka molumo o ts'epo haholo leha ho le joalo), "Ha ke na pepere ka kichineng ea ka ho hang. Sopho e etsa hantle haholo ntle le pelaelo hore e lula e le pepere e etsang hore batho ba be le mofuthu," o ile a tsoela pele, a thabile haholo hore ebe o fumane mofuta o mocha oa molao, "le asene e etsang hore ba bolila,+ le camomile e ba etsang hore ba be le tsoekere e bohloko le ea harese le lintho tse joalo tse etsang hore bana ba be monate. Ke lakatsa eka batho ba ne ba tseba feela hore: joale ba ne ba ke ke ba e-s'o khathatseha haholo ka eona, u se ke ua tseba hore u ka 'na ua e-ba joalo.'

tr_translation: The Duchess said, "I agree with you." "The lesson to be learned from this is: 'Let your outside be as your inside is, or, if you want it said more simply: 'Do not fall into the illusion that you can present yourself to everyone as different from what you are or could be.'"
es_translation: —Entirely agreed —said the Duchess—, and the moral of this is: "Be what you would seem to be" or, if you want me to put it more simply: "Never imagine yourself to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that you were or might have been was it not for what you were."

vi_translation: - As for me, I bring you a clear warning - the Queen screamed, stomping her feet furiously - Get out now or your head will be chopped off! There is no more time! Make your choice!
tr_translation: The Queen stomped her foot and shouted, "I'm telling you, either you leave here this instant, or you lose your head! Choose one of the two!"
es_translation: "—Now we are going to make things very clear," roared the Queen, stomping on the ground as she spoke—: "Either you or your head must disappear from the map!" "And in less than the blink of an eye! Choose!"

en: “You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—“Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.

vi_translation: - You are wrong. Under the sea, the flour would wash away. But it is true that they have tails in their mouths. And the reason is because… - At this point, Jia Ba Ba yawned and closed his eyes. Then he told the Lion-Headed Bird - Tell her the whole reason for this matter.
tr_translation: ''Crumbs?'' ''No way, there are no crumbs left in the sea, everything gets cleaned up.'' ''But their tails really are in their mouths.'' ''The reason for this is...'''' At this point, the Mock Turtle yawned and closed his eyes, saying to the Gryphon, ''You explain the reason!''
es_translation: —You're wrong about the bread —said the Mock Turtle—. In the sea, breadcrumbs would disappear immediately. But it's true that they carry their tails in their mouths, and the reason is... —At this point, the Mock Turtle yawned and closed her eyes—.

es: —Lo que digo yo— dijo la Tortuga, —es ¿de qué nos sirve tanto recitar y recitar? ¿Si no explicas el significado de los que estás diciendo! ¡Bueno! ¡Esto es lo más confuso que he oído en mi vida!
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Why are you reading all that nonsense when you aren't explaining anything at all? This is the most chaotic thing I've ever heard!
tr_translation: The Mock Turtle interrupted the poem, saying, "What's the use of repeating all these words if you're not going to explain them?" "I've never heard anything so confusing in my life!"
es_translation: —What I say— said the Turtle, —is what good does it do us to recite and recite so much? If you don't explain the meaning of what you are saying! Well! This is the most confusing thing I've heard in my life!

es: -Anotad todo esto -ordenó el Rey al jurado. Y los miembros del jurado se apresuraron a escribir las tres fechas en sus pizarras, y después sumaron las tres cifras y redujeron el resultado a chelines y peniques.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: - Write it down - the King told the jury. The jurors eagerly wrote down all three days on the board, then added them up and converted them into shillings and pence[22].
tr_translation: The king said to the council of judges, "Write these down!" and they grabbed their pens and recorded three historical events on their boards. Then, after gathering everything, they calculated the answer in lira and kuruş.
es_translation: "Write all this down," ordered the King to the jury. And the members of the jury hurried to write the three dates on their slates, and then added the three figures and reduced the result to shillings and pence.

es: Esto no pareció animar al testigo en absoluto: se apoyaba ora sobre un pie ora sobre el otro, miraba inquieto a la Reina, y era tal su confusión que dio un tremendo mordisco a la taza de té creyendo que se trataba del pan con mantequilla.

vi_translation: He kept shifting from one foot to the other and anxiously looked at the Queen. In his confusion, instead of biting the cake, he took a huge bite out of the teacup.
tr_translation: These words did not calm the witness at all; the poor thing kept shifting feet and looked anxiously at the Queen; in his confusion, thinking he was biting into a buttered bread, he bit into the tea cup and took a big chunk out of it!
es_translation: This did not seem to cheer up the witness at all: he leaned now on one foot, now on the other, looked anxiously at the Queen, and was so confused that he took a tremendous bite out of the teacup, thinking it was the bread and butter.

en: “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”

vi_translation: - Your Majesty, I am just a poor man - The hat maker began to speak with a trembling voice - For more than a week, or even longer, I haven't had any tea. My buttered bread is getting thinner and thinner, and the tea is so diluted that it sparkles like water... -
tr_translation: The hatter began to speak in a trembling voice: ''I am a poor man, Your Majesty!'' he said. ''I had just started my tea... It’s been about a week, more or less... Then both the buttered bread decreased... and the tea crackled...''
es_translation: "I am a poor man, Your Majesty," the Hatter began to say in a trembling voice, "... and I hadn't even started to have tea yet... it must have been less than a week... and the slices of bread and butter were getting thinner and thinner... and the flickering of the tea..."

en: “All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: “‘We know it to be true—’ that’s the jury, of course—‘I gave her one, they gave him two—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—”

es: —Hasta aquí todo encaja —observó el Rey, y siguió murmurando para sí mientras examinaba los versos—: Bien sabemos que es verdad... Evidentemente se refiere al jurado... Pero si ella insistiera... Tiene que ser la Reina... ¿Qué te podría pasar?... ¿Qué, en efecto? Yo di una, ellos dos... Vaya, esto debe ser lo que él hizo con las tartas...
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: - Alright, let's leave it at that for now – the King said and continued to mumble the next verse: “We know it to be true” This is indeed the jury, of course. “I give her one, they give him two.” Why, surely that's what he did with the fruit pies, you know.
tr_translation: The King said, "So far so good," and muttered the other lines to himself: "As if we never knew, as if we never saw." Of course, the judges' panel says this. I gave one to the lady, the others gave two. This must explain what she did with the buns.''
es_translation: —So far everything fits —remarked the King, and continued murmuring to himself while examining the verses—: We well know it is true... It evidently refers to the jury... But if she insisted... It has to be the Queen... What could happen to you?... What, indeed? I gave one, they two... Well, this must be what he did with the tarts...

vi_translation: The King muttered in self-pity: "This is just a wordplay." And then everyone laughed. - Jury, please consider the verdict – ordered the King. That day, he had said this sentence twenty times.
tr_translation: The king, as if offended, said, "This will be a word game," and everyone laughed. The king, perhaps for the twentieth time that day, commanded, "Let the council of judges announce their decision now."
es_translation: —It's a play on words! —the King had to explain acrimoniously. And now everyone laughed. —Let the jury consider its verdict! —ordered the King, for the hundredth time that day.

en: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
vi: Các người chẳng qua chỉ là một bộ bài mà thôi! – Alice nói (Lúc này cô đã cao lớn đúng bằng kích thước thật của mình). Alice vừa dứt lời thì cả bộ bài đều bay lên không trung rồi đổ ập xuống người cô. Alice hét lên một tiếng nhỏ, nửa khiếp sợ nửa tức giận, cô cố gắng gạt các quân bài ra khỏi người và bỗng nhiên cô thấy mình nằm trên bờ ruộng, đầu gối lên vạt áo của chị cô. Chị cô đang nhẹ nhàng gạt những chiếc là từ trên cây rơi xuống mặt cô.

es: Al oír esto la baraja se elevó por los aires y se precipitó en picada contra ella. Alicia dio un pequeño grito, mitad de miedo y mitad de enfado, e intentó sacárselos de encima... Y se encontró tumbada en la ribera, con la cabeza apoyada en la falda de su hermana, que le estaba quitando cariñosamente de la cara unas hojas secas que habían caído desde los árboles.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el país de las maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: – Alice said (At this moment, she had grown to her full size). As soon as Alice finished speaking, the entire deck of cards flew into the air and then came crashing down on her. Alice let out a small scream, half frightened and half angry, she tried to brush the cards off herself and suddenly found herself lying on the edge of a field, her head resting on her sister's lap. Her sister was gently brushing away the leaves that had fallen from the trees onto her face.
tr_translation: As soon as she said this, the whole deck started to fly up and fall on Alice. While Alice, half scared and half angry, was trying to fend off the cards with a scream, she suddenly found herself lying with her head on her sister's lap by the riverbank, and her sister was gently brushing away the dry leaves that had fallen from the trees.
es_translation: Upon hearing this, the deck of cards rose into the air and swooped down against her. Alice let out a small cry, half of fear and half of anger, and tried to get them off her... And she found herself lying on the riverbank, with her head resting on her sister's lap, who was gently removing some dry leaves from her face that had fallen from the trees.

en: So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality—the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds—the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy—and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard—while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
vi: Vì thế cô cứ ngồi lại trên bờ ruộng, hai mắt khéo hờ và mơ màng thấy mình đang ở xứ sở diệu kỳ. Cô biết rằng chỉ cần cô mở mắt ra là tất cả những hình ảnh đó sẽ lập tức biến thành thực tại tẻ ngắt. Ngọn cỏ chỉ xào xạc khi gió thổi và trong ao chỉ có những cây sậy đang nhẹ đưa trong làn nước róc rách chảy. – tiếng cốc chạm nhau sẽ biến thành tiếng chuông gọi cừu về tiếng gào thét chói tai của Hoàng hậu cũng biến thành tiếng cậu bé chăn cừu. Rồi tiếng hắt hơi của đứa bé, tiếng kêu thét của Sư tử đầu chim và tất cả những âm thanh kỳ dị khác sẽ biến thành tiếng hò hét hỗn loạn trong cái trang trại náo nhiệt phía xa (cô biết rõ điều đó). - Ở đó, tiếng rống của đàn gia súc sẽ thay thế tiếng nức nở não nề của Giả Ba Ba.

tr: Kraliçe'nin kulak tırmalayan sesiyle zavallı konuklarını idama mahkûm ettiğini duyar gibi oldu; bir kez daha çevresinde tabaklar çanaklar uçar dururken yavru domuz Düşes'in kucağında aksırdı; bir kez daha Ejder haykırdı, Kertenkele taş tahtasının kalemini gıcırdattı; susturulan kobaylar derinden derine ses verdiler; bunlara zavallı Yalancı Kaplumbağa'nın uzaktan uzağa duyulan hıçkırıkları karıştı. Öylece gözleri kapalı otururken kendini gerçekten Harikalar Ülkesi'nde sandı; ama biliyordu ki gözlerini bir açsa, her şey aslındaki donuk rengini alacak: otlar rüzgârda hışırdıyor, havuz sallanan sazlara uyarak şıpırdıyor olacak; çay fincanlarının şıkırtısının yerine koyun çıngıraklarının sesi, Kraliçe'nin çığlıklarının yerine çobanın seslenişi duyulacak; yavru domuzun aksırığı, Ejder'in haykırışı, özetle bütün o acayip seslerin yerine (biliyordu ki) durmadan işleyen çiftliğin gürültüsü patırtısı gelecek! Yalancı Kaplumbağa'nın hıçkırıklarının yerini de uzaktan uzağa ineklerin böğürmesi alacak...
es: La hermana de Alicia estaba sentada allí, con los ojos cerrados, y casi creyó encontrarse ella también en el País de las Maravillas. Pero sabía que le bastaba volver a abrir los ojos para encontrarse de golpe en la aburrida realidad. La hierba sería sólo agitada por el viento, y el chapoteo del estanque se debería al temblor de las cañas que crecían en él. El tintineo de las tazas de té se transformaría en el resonar de unos cencerros, y la penetrante voz de la Reina en los gritos de un pastor. Y los estornudos del bebé, los graznidos del Grifo, y todos los otros ruidos misteriosos, se transformarían (ella lo sabía) en el confuso rumor que llegaba desde una granja vecina, mientras el lejano balar de los rebaños sustituía los sollozos de la Falsa Tortuga.
es_results: "title": "Alicia en el País de las Maravillas","author": "Lewis Carroll"
vi_translation: Therefore, she just sat on the edge of the field, her eyes half-closed, dreamily imagining herself in a magical land. She knew that as soon as she opened her eyes, all those images would immediately turn into a dull reality. The grass only rustled when the wind blew, and in the pond, only the reeds gently swayed in the trickling water. - the clinking of cups would turn into the sound of bells calling the sheep, and the Queen's shrill screams would turn into the shepherd boy's cries. Then the child's sneeze, the Lion-headed bird's screech, and all the other strange sounds would turn into the chaotic shouts from the bustling farm in the distance (she knew this well). - There, the cattle's roars would replace the mournful sobs of the False Baba.
tr_translation: She seemed to hear the Queen's grating voice condemning her poor guests to death; once again, dishes and plates flew around as the baby pig sneezed in the Duchess's lap; once again, the Gryphon roared, the Lizard scratched its pencil on the slate; the silenced guinea pigs made deep sounds; and the distant sobs of the poor Mock Turtle mingled with these. While sitting with her eyes closed like that, she truly thought she was in Wonderland; but she knew that if she opened her eyes, everything would take on its dull color: the grass would rustle in the wind, the pond would ripple in response to the swaying reeds; instead of the clinking of tea cups, the sound of sheep bells would be heard, instead of the Queen's screams, the shepherd's calls would be heard; the piglet's sneeze, the Dragon's roar, in short, all those strange sounds would be replaced (she knew) by the continuous noise and clatter of the working farm! The distant mooing of cows would replace the Mock Turtle's sobs...
es_translation: Alice's sister was sitting there, with her eyes closed, and she almost believed she was also in Wonderland. But she knew that just by opening her eyes again, she would find herself suddenly in the boring reality. The grass would only be stirred by the wind, and the splashing of the pond would be due to the trembling of the reeds growing in it. The clinking of the tea cups would turn into the ringing of cowbells, and the piercing voice of the Queen into the shouts of a shepherd. And the baby's sneezes, the Gryphon's squawks, and all the other mysterious noises would (she knew) turn into the confused murmur coming from a nearby farm, while the distant bleating of the flocks would replace the sobs of the Mock Turtle.
st: O ile a lula, ka mahlo a koetsoeng, 'me halofo o ile a lumela ka boeena o Wonderland, Leha ho le joalo o ne a tseba hore o ne a tla empa ho bula bona hape, 'me bohle ba ne ba tla fetoha ho lerootho bonnete ba hore joang bo ne bo tla rustling ka moea, 'me letamo rippling ho waving la reding le tsoang li-teacups li ne li tla fetoha ho nahanaling linku-bells,  'Me mofumahali shrill o ile a lla ho lentsoe la moshanyana molisa eo a nyeheletsoeng,' me ho emola ea ngoana, shriek ea Gryphon, le li-queers tse ling kaofela li ne li tla fetoha (o ne a tseba) ho clamour e ferekaneng ea polasi e phetheselang ea polasing e phethetsoeng, ha ho ntse ho fokotseha ha likhomo ka hōjana ho ne ho tla nka sebaka sa li-sobs tse boima tsa Mock Turtle.
yo: Nítorí náà ó jókòó, pẹ̀lú ojú títì pa, ìdajì sì gbàgbọ́ nínú Wonderland, bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ó mọ̀ pé òun ní ṣùgbọ́n láti ṣí wọn lẹ́ẹ̀kan si, gbogbo rẹ̀ yóò sì yípadà sí òtítọ́ tí kò dára - koríko náà yóò kàn máa pọ́n nínú afẹ́fẹ́, odò ìwẹ̀ náà sì ń ya sí fífọ́ àwọn reeds - àwọn teacups tí ó ń fọ́ yóò yí padà sí àwọn agogo àgùntàn,  ayaba sì ń sunkún sí ohùn ọmọkùnrin olùṣọ́-àgùntàn náà - àti ẹ̀gàn ọmọ náà, ìkìlọ̀ Gryphon, àti gbogbo àwọn ariwo ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà yòókù, yóò yí padà (ó mọ̀) sí ìkìlọ̀ ìdàrúdàpọ̀ àgbàlá oko tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ - nígbà tí ìsàlẹ̀ màlúù ní ọ̀nà jíjìn yóò gba ààyè àwọn ẹkún mock Turtle tó wúwo.
tn: Ka jalo, o ne a ithaya a re o ne a itse gore o ne a sa ntse a na le ditshika tsa gagwe, mme o ne a itse gore o ne a na le go di bula gape, mme tsotlhe di ne di tla fetoga go fula bojang fela mo phefong.  16Mme mogadigadi o ne a lela ka lentswe la modisa a re: "Le thimola ngwana wa ga Gryphon, le modumo o mongwe le mongwe o o monate, o ne o tla fetoga (o ne a itse) go ya kwa lefelong le le rurufetseng la polase e e busy-yard,e bong e e kwa tlase ya dikgomo mo sekgaleng e ne e tla tsaya lefelo la sobs e e boima ya Sofi.
ty: No reira ua parahi noa oia, ma te mata tapiri, e ua ti'aturi te afaraa ia'na iho i roto i te fenua maere, noa'tu e ua ite oia e e iriti faahou â oia i te reira, e e taui te mau mea ato'a ei mea monamona—e tutae auri noa te aihere i roto i te mata'i, e te vahi hopuraa pape e tae roa'tu i te taheraa pape o te mau aeho—e taui ïa te mau uru raau rii ei raau parai,  e te ta'i o te arii vahine i te reo o te tia'i mamoe—e te ta'i o te aiû, te ruru o te Gryphon, e te tahi atu mau maniania, e taui ïa (ua ite oia) i te ta'i taa ore o te faaapu—area te ta'i o te mau puaatoro i te atea ê ra, e mono ïa i te ta'i teiaha o te Mock Turtle.
mai: तेँ ओ बंद आँखिसँ बैसि गेलीह, आ आधा वन्डरलैंडमे अपना पर विश्वास करैत छलीह, यद्यपि ओ जनैत छलीह जे हुनका लग फेरसँ खोलबाक अतिरिक्त अछि, आ सब किछु सुस्त वास्तविकतामे बदलि जायत - घास मात्र हवामे सरसराइत होयत, आ पूलक चीर-फाड़ नरकक लहराबै धरि - तेज चायक कप भेड़-घंटीमे बदलि जायत,  आ चरवाहा लड़काक आवाज पर रानीक तीखा चिल्लाहट - आ बच्चाक छींक, ग्रिफनक चिल्लाहट, आ आन सभ विचित्र आवाज, व्यस्त खेत-आँगनक भ्रमित चिल्लाहट मे बदलि जायत (ओ जनैत छलीह) - जखन कि दूर मे मवेशी के नीचा होयब मॉक कछुआ के भारी शोर के जगह लेत।
